table-wrap.anchoringText: To gain a general idea about the composition of several water types, Table 1 presents the average composition for three water sources: a) fresh water from rivers (Limay, Neuquén, and Colorado) or water wells, b) flow-back water from VM and tight-gas formations, and c) produced water from oilfield production plants. All the samples (150 tests) correspond to the Neuquina basin, while the flow-back water corresponds to samples collected during the first 10 days of initial well evaluation, with other samples after this initial comprising the produced water. In addition, the first column presents the requirements for fresh water use in the base element of a fracturing fluid (according to service company standards).
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Summary of water types.

table-wrap.anchoringText: One of the main requirements for this operator was to evaluate the feasibility of using produced water for the entire completion. Initially, the operator performed a survey for several alternative water sources (produced water from different wells) to determine the quality and quantity to be used. Table 2 presents the values for these sources.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Summary of the first group of samples evaluated.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of the first group of samples evaluated.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Several water types presented values outside the limit for pH, bicarbonate, calcium, and the total volume of water required for the operation was not enough. Following the first screening process, a second water source was evaluated (water for waterflooding project, Table 3). After the evaluation, this alternative water source was selected for use, and a filtration process was then applied (Aramayo et al. 2015).
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Summary of the second group of samples.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of the second group of samples.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Initial tests were performed with sample 1 to evaluate the performance of a guar-borate fluid that used two crosslinkers: a primary-delayed (XBor-c) and a secondary-instant (XBor-b). Some adjustments to the concentration of these crosslinkers were made to obtain a fluid that met the requirement. Additional tests were performed at two lower temperatures (125°F and 100°F) to improve the breaking profile, thereby changing the crosslinkers and breakers. Information on these tests (A, B, and C) is presented in Table 4 and Fig. 4.
table-wrap.label: Table 4
table-wrap.caption: Summary of fluid formulations and main characteristics.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of fluid formulations and main characteristics.

table-wrap.anchoringText: The completion was performed between February and March of 2014. The fourth fracture stages were performed in four days, with the main information for this treatment being presented in Table 5. Fig. 5 shows a panoramic view of the wellsite, Fig. 6 presents the treatment chart for the first frac stage. A total of 1.0 million of gallons of produced water were consumed throughout the entire treatment process, 49% of which comprised the gelling system and 30% was the crosslinked fluid (Fig. 7).
table-wrap.label: Table 5
table-wrap.caption: Summary of the main parameters for the hydraulic fracture performed.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of the main parameters for the hydraulic fracture performed.

table-wrap.anchoringText: The Magallanes formation is classified as a glauconitic sandstone of late Cretaceous and Tertiary age and is subdivided into three members (M1, M2, and M3). This reservoir produces gas and wet gas. General information on the stimulated members is presented in Table 6.
table-wrap.label: Table 6
table-wrap.caption: Summary of the main reservoir characteristics.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of the main reservoir characteristics.

table-wrap.anchoringText: The main objective of this project was to identify an alternative source of water that could be used in stimulations. An initial evaluation was performed by the operator to quantify the volume available (daily production) for different wells. After completing this analysis and selecting the well to be used, the operator provided a group of samples that were collected within a span of one month to a laboratory to determine their chemical composition (Table 7).
table-wrap.label: Table 7
table-wrap.caption: Summary of water characteristics.

table-wrap.anchoringText: An initial test consisted of comparing the performance of guar with deionized water and formation water to determine whether the water source would present some type of problem. A second group of tests evaluated different gelling agents, such as hydroxypropyl guar (HPG), and a double-derivatized carboxymethyl-hydroxypropyl guar (CMHPG) with the formation water. Table 8 presents the results for both early times (1 to 5 minutes) and final times (30 minutes) to provide information on the hydration rate and the final viscosity developed.
table-wrap.label: Table 8
table-wrap.caption: Hydration test.

table-wrap.anchoringText: This phase consisted of obtaining fluid formulations with a good rheology profile that would be stable for up to 60 minutes at 150°F. Four fluid formulations were evaluated to achieve the technical goals, and a cost evaluation was then performed to quantify the economic feasibility of these fluids and analyze their impacts on the project. Table 9 presents the main characteristics of these fluids.
table-wrap.label: Table 9
table-wrap.caption: Summary of properties of fluid formulations evaluated and cost evaluation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of properties of fluid formulations evaluated and cost evaluation.

table-wrap.anchoringText: The target for this stage was to perform a group of break tests at different temperatures to obtain a family of fluid formulations with several breaking times, as shown in Table 10 and Fig. 10. These formulations have been used in most of the treatments for both the conventional treatments (100%crosslinked) and the jobs using the hybrid design in vertical and horizontal wells. It is well established that for low temperatures, an expensive enzyme breaker is often applied. The breaker used for this fluid was an oxidizer, which was combined with a catalyst at 100°F to accelerate the breaking time. This breaker and catalyst did not negatively impact the cost of the fluid system.
table-wrap.label: Table 10
table-wrap.caption: Break test Evaluation.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Table 11 presents the values of three samples collected and analyzed. In general, several parameters were outside the limits permitted, the most significant of which was the TDS. These samples sent to the laboratory to develop a fracture fluid formulation that would meet the operational requirement.
table-wrap.label: Table 11
table-wrap.caption: Summary of water characteristics.

table-wrap.anchoringText: The initial test compared the performance of guar with deionized water and produced water. The next step was to evaluate different gelling agents, such as guar and carboxymethyl-hydroxypropyl guar (CMHPG), with produced water. The results (Table 12) showed a lower final viscosity in the guar system using produced water, but a fast hydration. A better response was observed for CMHPG.
table-wrap.label: Table 12
table-wrap.caption: Hydration tests.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Fluid formulations with a good rheology profile were developed to be stable for 60 minutes at 100°F. Three fluids systems were obtained according the objective for this operation. Table 13 presents information on the properties of these formulations.
table-wrap.label: Table 13
table-wrap.caption: Summary of properties of fluid formulations evaluated and cost evaluation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of properties of fluid formulations evaluated and cost evaluation.

table-wrap.anchoringText: The primary objective for this phase was to validate the break test at two temperatures: 100°F and 75°F. A highly concentrated enzymatic breaker was used for the lower temperature. Table 14 presents the formulation and primary characteristics of this system. Initial tests (A and C) were performed for the two required temperatures, and a longer break time was observed. A second group of tests (B and D) was performed, in which two temperature ramps (first 60 minutes at 100°F and the second 60 minutes at 120°F, simulating a reservoir condition) was programmed in order to prevent increasing the breaker and associated cost for this system.
table-wrap.label: Table 14
table-wrap.caption: Break test evaluation.
